channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: How Russia Lost an Epic Tank Battle, Repeating Earlier Mistakes
item.description: A three-week fight in the town of Vuhledar in southern Ukraine produced what Ukrainian officials say was the biggest tank battle of the war so far, and a stinging setback for the Russians.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukraine’s 72nd Brigade near Vuhledar, in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Blinken Says He Sees No Sign That Putin Wants Peace
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken concluded a visit to Central Asia, where he reiterated U.S. support for a region that has long been in Moscow’s sphere. Here is what we’re covering:
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Bola Tinubu Elected to Be Nigeria’s Next President
item.description: Bola Tinubu, declared the winner on Wednesday in the presidential election, has boasted of making the careers of major politicians. Now he has to deliver for a divided country facing multiple emergencies.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Bola Tinubu celebrating with supporters at his party’s campaign headquarters after winning the presidential elections in Abuja, Nigeria, on Wednesday.

item.title: Video: How an Israeli Raid on a Safe House Ended With Civilians Killed
item.description: A New York Times analysis of videos shows how an Israeli raid to capture Palestinian gunmen rippled into one of the most violent encounters in the West Bank in decades.
item.dc:creator: Haley Willis, Christiaan Triebert, Hiba Yazbek and Patrick Kingsley

item.title: Bola Tinubu’s Victory Extends His Party’s Time in Power in Nigeria
item.description: Mr. Tinubu asked the opposition to work with him as Africa’s most populous country navigates an economic crisis. Opponents said the election was marred by fraud, and the running mate of one said they would contest the results.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Greece Train Crash: At Least 38 Dead as Rescuers Search for Survivors
item.description: A train with over 300 passengers on board collided with a freight train. Two of the carriages “basically don’t exist anymore,” a regional governor said, and the transport minister announced his resignation.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times

item.title: Eritrea Faces Growing Scrutiny for Role in Ethiopia’s War in Tigray
item.description: Eritrean troops have been accused of war crimes in the northern Tigray region just weeks before a peace agreement was signed last year.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Simon Marks
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A satellite image showing military equipment positioned in the village of Serha in Eritrea, across the border from the town of Zalambessa in the Tigray region of northern Ethiopia in September.

item.title: Finland on Cusp of Joining NATO, but Maybe Not With Sweden
item.description: The Nordic partners wanted to join together, but with Turkey holding up Sweden’s application, Helsinki will reluctantly enter alone to ensure its security.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: The vote by Finland’s Parliament on Wednesday is subject to ratification by the Parliaments of Turkey and Hungary.

item.title: Israeli Police Use Stun Grenades on Protesters in Tel Aviv
item.description: The confrontations escalated tensions between the political leadership and protesters opposed to the far-right government’s plan to curb the powers of the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Police officers hold back demonstrators blocking a road in the city center during an antigovernment protest in Tel Aviv on Wednesday. Several protesters were arrested or injured.

item.title: Turkey’s Earthquake Will Not Delay Elections in Country, Erdogan Says
item.description: The Feb. 6 earthquake’s vast destruction will present a challenge when it comes to mounting a viable election. But President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said the vote would go on in May, “God willing.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey speaking on Wednesday during a party meeting in Turkey’s capital, Ankara.

item.title: ‘A Strange Dream’: A Cruise Ship Is a Floating Shelter for Displaced Turks
item.description: More than 1,000 Turkish residents displaced by the recent earthquakes are staying on a luxury boat in the Mediterranean Sea.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht, Nimet Kirac and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I would never have guessed that I would be on a cruise to nowhere at a moment like this,” said Basak Atay, who lost family and friends in the quake.

item.title: South Africa’s Embattled Deputy President Resigns
item.description: Despite scandal and controversy, David Mabuza remained in office for five years, only leaving once he had lost power within the governing African National Congress party.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, center, and David Mabuza, the deputy president, right, in December.

item.title: What Is the Northern Ireland Protocol? The Brexit Deal Changes, Explained
item.description: Britain and the European Union have long clashed over post-Brexit rules known as the Northern Ireland protocol. Here’s how their renegotiated agreement will work.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle, Megan Specia and Peter Robins
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carlingford Lough, with Northern Ireland on the left and Ireland on the right. The inlet marks the border.

item.title: What’s Behind the Vegetable Shortages in U.K. Supermarkets
item.description: Five major grocery chains are restricting the number of some produce items, as bad weather in Spain leads to shortages.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Tesco is among several British grocery chains that are limiting the number of tomatoes that customers can buy.

item.title: Peter Obi, Third-Party Candidate in Nigeria Election, Refuses to Concede
item.description: Peter Obi was until recently a secondary player in Nigerian politics. By switching parties and appealing to the digitally savvy, he overturned the old order.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Obi campaigning in Lagos, Nigeria’s largest city, on Feb. 11.

item.title: Foreign Adversaries Unlikely to Blame for Havana Syndrome, Intelligence Review Finds
item.description: The assessment also concluded that there was no “credible evidence” that any adversaries had developed a weapon capable of causing the injuries that U.S. officials have reported.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Entous
item.media:description: The U.S. Embassy in Havana, where the first reports of the mysterious ailments emerged. Some victims believe the episodes were caused by a foreign power.

item.title: Why Brexit’s immigration politics have fizzled out
item.description: Did the Northern Ireland trade deal end Brexit politics with a whimper?
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain and Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, speaking about details of the Northern Ireland trade deal this week.

item.title: Ukraine Says It’s Sending Reinforcements to Bakhmut
item.description: In recent weeks, Russian forces have been rushed to the front line, helping Moscow seize villages and towns around Bakhmut and surround the city on three sides.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a rocket launcher position in the Bakhmut area on Tuesday.

item.title: Denmark Scraps ‘Great Prayer Day,’ Adding Money to Military Budget
item.description: The government estimated that eliminating Great Prayer Day would produce $430 million that it could spend on the military.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered in Copenhagen on Feb. 5 to protest the government’s plans to eliminate the Great Prayer Day holiday.

item.title: China’s Factories Report Surge in Activity After Lockdowns End
item.description: Manufacturing activity rose in February to its highest level in more than a decade, bolstering China’s recovery after restrictions paralyzed much of the country.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: An assembly line at a Wuling Motors factory in Qingdao, a city in China’s Shandong Province.

item.title: Chicago Votes for Change
item.description: After a crime surge, Chicago voters have ousted their current mayor.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paul Vallas voting in Chicago yesterday.

item.title: The 15-Minute City: Where Urban Planning Meets Conspiracy Theories
item.description: Is having all of life’s amenities within a 15-minute walk convenient? Or is it a government leash? We explain.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford
item.media:description: The mayor of Paris has embraced the concept of so-called 15-minute cities, in which residents live near all of their daily needs.

item.title: U.S. fears Lukashenko’s visit to China is strengthening ties between Russia’s closest allies.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus arriving in Beijing on Tuesday, in a handout photo from the Belarusian state-owned news agency.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Concerns about U.S. spending on aid to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers loading a weapon onto an armored vehicle.

item.title: Who is Bola Tinubu, Nigeria’s President Elect?
item.description: Mr. Tinubu, a former governor of Lagos and the ruling party candidate, campaigned using the slogan “It’s my turn.” He promised to address widespread insecurity and economic woes, but he faced concerns about his fitness for office.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: A portrait of Bola Tinubu of the All Progressives Congress, at a party press conference in Abuja, Nigeria, on Monday.

item.title: Foreign Efforts to Subvert Canada’s Last 2 Elections Failed, Report Says
item.description: An independent review found that China, Russia and Iran tried to interfere in the 2019 and 2021 votes, but that the elections’ integrity was not compromised.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada campaigning in Burnaby, British Columbia, in 2021. A report says China, Russia and Iran tried to influence the election that year.

item.title: Train Crash Kills at Least 32 in Greece
item.description: A train with about 350 passengers aboard collided with an oncoming freight train, officials said. At least 25 people were hospitalized with serious injuries.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times

item.title: Blinken Finds Receptive Leaders in Central Asia, Where Russia Seeks Aid
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state’s diplomatic mission is part of a broader Biden administration effort to strengthen support for Ukraine, or at least push neutral nations to refrain from aiding Russia.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: The U.S. secretary of state, Antony J. Blinken, and the Kazakh president, Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, in Astana, Kazakhstan, on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia Accuses Ukraine of Launching Drone Strikes Over its Territory
item.description: The Ukrainian government publicly follows a policy of deliberate ambiguity about strikes on Russian territory.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Administration of the Kursk region of Russia, via Associated Press

item.title: Netanyahu’s Grip Loosens Amid Israel Turmoil
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu promised stability, but two months into his new tenure, Israeli divisions have deepened, West Bank violence has escalated and splits have emerged in his coalition.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at a cabinet meeting this month in Jerusalem.

item.title: How Environmentally Conscious Investing Became a Target of Conservatives
item.description: The business world has been pulled into partisan politics, with Republicans bringing their battle against socially conscious investing to Congress.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:description: Representative Patrick McHenry recently announced a “Republican E.S.G. Working Group” that would question executives on their views about climate change and social issues.

item.title: Biden’s Semiconductor Plan Bets on Federal Aid to Change Corporate Behavior
item.description: The administration says the conditions it has attached to $40 billion in new subsidies will help U.S. semiconductor makers compete globally. Some economists disagree.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s industrial policy aims to accomplish multiple goals at the same time. But the strategy also carries risks.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A U.S. Push to Isolate Russia
item.description: Also, China’s attempt to erase “zero Covid” and Nigeria’s contested election.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik and Mariah Kreutter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken, left, meeting with Kazakhstan’s foreign minister, Mukhtar Tleuberdi.

item.title: King Charles Faces Backlash Over E.U. Meeting
item.description: King Charles’s meeting with an E.U. leader on the day a Northern Ireland trade deal was announced drew angry recriminations from critics who viewed it as an improper foray into British politics.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III and the European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, met on Monday for tea at Windsor Castle.

item.title: Satellite Imagery Shows Possible Damage to Russian Plane in Belarus
item.description: The British Ministry of Defense said that the loss of the plane would be significant if confirmed, “as it is critical to Russian air operations for providing an air battle space picture.”
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl

item.title: China Welcomes Belarusian Leader Amid Concerns About Ukraine
item.description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko’s visit comes shortly after the United States accused Beijing of preparing to give arms and ammunition to Russia to help its war on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, right, with President Alexander Lukashenko of Belarus in 2016 during a visit to Beijing.

item.title: Nigeria Election Tainted by Accusations of Vote Rigging
item.description: Two parties say the presidential vote in Africa’s biggest democracy was marred by fraud and violence, and they called for the head of the election commission to step down.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Election results from Nigerian states being read out at in Abuja on Tuesday.

item.title: Situation in Bakhmut Is ‘Getting More and More Difficult,' Zelensky Says
item.description: The eastern city, which had a prewar population of around 70,000 people, has become a focus of the fighting, with both sides pouring in troops and taking significant losses.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Buildings damaged by a Russian military strike in the frontline city of Bakhmut, on Monday.

item.title: A Challenge to Student Debt Relief
item.description: The Supreme Court could strike down a program meant to help 40 million borrowers.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden speaking about student loan forgiveness at Delaware State University in December.

item.title: Sunak Hopes to Move Past Brexit, at Long Last, With E.U. Deal
item.description: In addition to removing an obstacle to London-Brussels relations, the Northern Ireland trade deal could remove Brexit from the center of British politics after seven divisive years.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak in Windsor on Monday.

item.title: Europe Struggles to Find Leopard 2 Tanks for Ukraine
item.description: The struggle to deliver on promises to provide Leopard 2 tanks for use against Russian forces has exposed just how unprepared European militaries are.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military personnel at a media event at a base in Swietoszow, Poland in February. The event was to display to the public how the Polish military trains Ukrainian soldiers on the German-made Leopard 2 tanks.

item.title: China Moves to Erase the Vestiges of ‘Zero Covid’ to Deter Dissent
item.description: The ruling Communist Party is waging an ambitious propaganda campaign to rewrite the public’s memory of its handling of the pandemic, which included some of the harshest restrictions in the world.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong and Zixu Wang
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: Removing a Covid testing booth at a park in Beijing. The booths, once ubiquitous symbols of China’s strict “zero Covid” policy, are now empty or converted into new uses.

item.title: C.S. Lewis’s Oxford: Where the Lion and the Witch Met the Hobbit
item.description: Discovering the sites in Oxford where C.S. Lewis, the writer of over 30 books, including the “Chronicles of Narnia” series, found faith, inspiration and a life-changing friendship with J.R.R. Tolkien.
item.dc:creator: Will Higginbotham and Max Miechowski
item.media:credit: Max Miechowski for The New York Times

item.title: Burger King Is Hungry Jack’s in Australia. What Will Wendy’s Be?
item.description: The American burger chain plans to enter the Australian market. The problem? There’s already a fast food company down under with the same name.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Wendy’s, the American hamburger chain, is considering opening restaurants in Australia.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Britain’s prime minister, Rishi Sunak, and Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, announced the deal, which they called the “Windsor Framework,” on Monday.

item.title: Hong Kong Mask Mandate, One of World’s Last, Will End
item.description: As of Wednesday, the city will no longer require people to wear masks indoors, outdoors or on public transportation.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hong Kong’s mask mandate has been in effect since July 2020.

item.title: What We Know About the Lab Leak Theory and the Origins of Covid
item.description: Scientists and spy agencies have tried to determine where the coronavirus originated, but conclusive evidence is hard to come by and the nation’s intelligence agencies are split.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: The Wuhan Institute of Virology in 2021. The U.S. Energy Department has concluded with “low confidence” that an accidental laboratory leak in China most likely caused the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Ahmed Qurei, Former Palestinian Premier and Peace Envoy, Dies at 86
item.description: A member of the old guard of Palestinian leaders, Mr. Qurei was a principal architect of the Oslo Accords, the first peace agreement with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Ahmed Qurei in 2005, when he was the Palestinian prime minister. In the 1990s, he led the Palestinian side in negotiating the Oslo Accords.

item.title: To Heal Brexit Wound, U.K. and E.U. Strike a Northern Ireland Trade Deal
item.description: A dispute left over from the Britain-European Union split has chilled relations, paralyzed Northern Ireland’s government, risked a trade war and even caused friction between London and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Britain’s prime minister, Rishi Sunak, and Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, announced the deal, which they called the “Windsor Framework,” on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: U.S. Treasury Secretary Visits Kyiv
item.description: Also, Britain and the E.U. agree on a Northern Ireland trade deal and winter devastates Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen laid flowers to a Memory Wall of Fallen Defenders of Ukraine in the Russian-Ukrainian War during her visit to Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Biden Dispatches Yellen and Blinken to Bolster Support for Ukraine
item.description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen traveled to Kyiv the day before Secretary of State Antony Blinken was to visit Central Asia in a show of American solidarity with Ukraine in its battle with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen and Bridget Brink, the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, placed flowers at the memorial wall of St. Michael’s Golden-Domed Cathedral in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Migrant Deaths Shine Light on Europe’s Broken Promises
item.description: At least 63 people died in a shipwreck off Italy’s coast, reviving memories of a crash in 2013 that killed hundreds and the work that did not get done in its aftermath.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Gaia Pianigiani
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: A memorial for the shipwreck’s victims near Cutro, Italy, on Monday.

item.title: An Elf? A Witch? Mexico’s President Says It’s the Mythical Aluxe
item.description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador tweeted an image of what he said was an aluxe, a legendary elflike creature. News outlets said it looked like a 2021 photo of another questionable creature.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez

item.title: In Central Asia, Blinken Will Urge Distance From Russia, and Ukraine War
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken is making the first trip by a Biden administration cabinet official to the former Soviet republics of Central Asia.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Anton Troianovski and Stanley Reed
item.media:description: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, will meet with foreign ministers from five Central Asian republics.

item.title: Betty Boothroyd, Britain’s First Female House of Commons Speaker, Dies at 93
item.description: The speaker made Britain’s parliamentary proceedings must-see TV, even in other countries.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Jeff Overs/BBC News & Current Affairs, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Betty Boothroyd in 2000. When she was named speaker as a member of the opposition Labour Party in 1992, there were just 60 women in the 651-member House of Commons.

item.title: King Charles Met E.U. Leader Ahead of New Brexit Deal, Sparking Controversy
item.description: Some said the meeting conflicted with the king’s apolitical role because it came at the time Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, was finalizing the new Brexit deal.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III, left, with Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, at Windsor Castle on Monday.

item.title: Northern Lights Seen Across the U.K. in Rare Show
item.description: The sight, which usually involves a trip to a snowy outpost, could be seen in the south of England.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The northern lights over the Trossachs in Scotland on Sunday.
